{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2016}} [[File:Falcon 9 first stage at LZ-1(two).jpg|thumb|upright=1.5|The first stage of [[Falcon 9 flight 20]] successfully landed for the first time on a ground pad at [[Landing Zone 1]], [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]], after propelling 11 [[Orbcomm]] [[Orbcomm (satellite)|OG2 satellites]] to orbit.]]
The '''[[Falcon 9]] first-stage landing tests''' were a series of controlled-descent [[flight test]]s conducted by [[SpaceX]] between 2013 and 2016. Since 2017, the first stage of Falcon 9 missions has been routinely landed if the rocket performance allowed it, and if SpaceX chose to recover the stage.<!-- in the early days of routine operation, this was fairly one-dimensional: recover if rocket performance allows. By early 2018 however, with a number of Block 4 "flight-proven" boosters in stock, and an explicit decision by SpaceX to re-fly Block 3 boosters only once (two total flights), some second-flight boosters began to be expended EVEN THOUGH rocket performance would have allowed recovery. That's a fact. I've not found a source explaining why, so saying all of this in article prose would be speculation. -->
The program's objective was to reliably execute controlled re-entry, descent and landing ([[EDL (rocketry)|EDL]]) of the Falcon 9 [[first stage (rocketry)|first stage]] into Earth's atmosphere after the stage completes the boost phase of an [[orbital spaceflight]]. The first tests aimed to touch down vertically in the ocean at zero velocity. Later tests attempted to land the rocket precisely on an [[autonomous spaceport drone ship]] (a barge commissioned by SpaceX to provide a stable landing surface at sea) or at [[Landing Zone 1]] (LZ-1), a concrete pad at [[CCAFS|Cape Canaveral]]. The first ground landing at LZ-1 succeeded in December 2015, and the first landing at sea on a drone ship in April 2016. The second landed booster, [[B1021]], was the first to fly again in March 2017, and was recovered a second time.
{{columns-start}} {{column}} {{TOC left}} {{column}} {{center|'''Landings of Falcon 9 first-stage boosters'''}} {{#section-h::List of Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy launches|Booster recovery}} {{columns-end}}
== Overview == The first landing test occurred in September 2013 on the [[#Flight 6|sixth flight]] of a Falcon 9 and maiden launch of the [[Falcon 9 v1.1|v1.1 rocket version]]. From 2013 to 2016, sixteen test flights were conducted, six of which achieved a soft landing and recovery of the booster: * [[#Flight 20: first landing on ground pad|flight 20]] ([[Orbcomm OG2 M2]]) safely touching down on the [[Landing Zone 1|LZ-1]] ground pad upon first attempt in December 2015; * [[#Flight 23: first landing on floating platform (drone ship)|flight 23]] ([[CRS-8]]) finally achieving a stable landing at sea in the [[Atlantic Ocean|Atlantic]] on the drone ship ''[[Of Course I Still Love You]]'' in April 2016 after four previous attempts ended in destruction of the booster upon impact; * flights [[#Flight 24: first return from GTO mission|24]] ([[JCSAT-14]]) and [[#Flight 25|25]] ([[Thaicom 8]]) returning at higher speed from [[geosynchronous transfer orbit|GTO]] missions at sea on a drone ship in May 2016; * [[#Flight 27|flight 27]] ([[CRS-9]]) returning to LZ-1 in July 2016; * [[#Flight 28|flight 28]] ([[JCSAT-16]]) landing on a drone ship in August 2016;
Since the January 2017 return to flight, SpaceX has stopped referring to landing attempts as "experimental", indicating that they have become a routine procedure (see [http://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/spacex_iridium1_press_kit.pdf Iridium-1] and [http://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/crs10presskitfinal.pdf CRS-10] press kits of 2017, compared with [http://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/spacex_crs9_press_kit.pdf CRS-9] and [http://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/spacex_jcsat16_press_kit.pdf JCSAT-16] of 2016). {{As of|2017|12|15}}, 14 routine landings<!-- UPDATE after each flight --> have been performed ({{percent|14|14}}<!-- UPDATE after each landed flight --> success) and three missions<!-- UPDATE after each expended flight --> were launched in [[expendable launch system|expendable]] configuration, not attempting to land.
The first-stage descent tests were part of the larger [[SpaceX reusable launch system development program]], which included a large amount of [[new product development|new technology development]] activities and earlier low-altitude test flights at the [[SpaceX McGregor|SpaceX facility]] in [[McGregor, Texas]] in preparation for the high-altitude high-velocity testing of landing test phase of the program. The overall objective of the program is to [[private spaceflight|privately develop]] [[reusable launch vehicle|reusable rockets]] using [[VTVL|vertical-landing]] technology so as to substantially reduce the cost of space access.
Traditionally, the first stages of orbital carrier rockets have been [[Expendable launch system|discarded in the ocean]] once the ascent was complete. Achieving routine recovery and reuse of the launch vehicles could dramatically reduce the cost of access to space.<ref name="bbc20130930"> {{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-24331860 |title=Recycled rockets: SpaceX calls time on expendable launch vehicles |work=BBC News |last=Amos |first=Jonathan |date=September 30, 2013 |accessdate=October 2, 2013}}</ref><ref name=tsr20140310> {{cite journal |last=Boozer |first=R.D. |title=Rocket reusability: a driver of economic growth |journal=The Space Review |date=March 10, 2014 |url=http://www.thespacereview.com/article/2466/1 |accessdate=March 25, 2014}}</ref><ref name=mtr20140313> {{cite news |last=Belfiore |first=Michael |title=SpaceX Set to Launch the World's First Reusable Booster |url=http://www.technologyreview.com/news/525426/spacex-set-to-launch-the-worlds-first-reusable-booster/ |accessdate=March 14, 2014 |newspaper=MIT Technology Review |date=March 13, 2014 |quote=SpaceX is counting on lower launch costs to increase demand for launch services. But Foust cautions that this strategy comes with risk. 'It's worth noting,' he says, 'that many current customers of launch services, including operators of commercial satellites, aren't particularly price sensitive, so thus aren't counting on reusability to lower costs.' That means those additional launches, and thus revenue, may have to come from markets that don't exist yet. 'A reusable system with much lower launch costs might actually result in lower revenue for that company unless they can significantly increase demand,' says Foust. 'That additional demand would likely have to come from new markets, with commercial human spaceflight perhaps the biggest and best-known example.'}}</ref><ref name=cnbc20150113> {{cite web |last1=Wells|first1=Jane |title=SpaceX, Elon Musk and the reusable rocket dream |url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/102334275 |website=CNBC |publisher=Comcast |accessdate=April 23, 2015 |date=January 13, 2015 }}</ref>
== History ==
SpaceX first announced in March 2013 that it would instrument and equip subsequent Falcon 9 first stages as controlled-descent test vehicles, able to propulsively decelerate towards a soft touchdown over the water surface. The company expected to begin these flight tests in 2013, with an attempt to return the vehicle to the launch site for a powered landing no earlier than mid-2014.<ref name="pa20130328-2"> {{cite news |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2013/03/28/dragon-post-mission-press-conference-notes/ |title=Dragon Post-Mission Press Conference Notes |work=Parabolic Arc |last=Messier |first=Doug |date=March 28, 2013 |accessdate=March 30, 2013 |quote=Q. What is strategy on first stage recover? Musk: Initial recovery test will be a water landing. First stage continue in ballistic arc and execute a velocity reduction burn before it enters atmosphere to lessen impact. Right before splashdown, will light up the engine again. Emphasizes that we don’t expect success in the first several attempts. Hopefully next year with more experience and data, we should be able to return the first stage to the launch site and do a propulsion landing on land using legs. Q. Is there a flight identified for return to launch site of the first stage? Musk: No. Will probably be the middle of next year.}}</ref>
In the event, SpaceX did perform their first controlled-descent test flight in 2013 but continued the over-water testing well into 2015. Following analysis of telemetry data from the first controlled descent in September 2013, SpaceX announced that a large amount of new technology passed their real-life test objectives, and that coupled with the technology advancements made on the [[Grasshopper (rocket)|Grasshopper]] low-altitude landing demonstrator, they were now ready to test the full EDL process to recover the first stage. The rocket was "able to successfully transition from vacuum through [[hypersonic]], through [[supersonic]], through [[transonic]], and light the engines all the way and control the stage all the way through [the atmosphere]".<ref name=pm20130930> {{cite news |url=http://www.popularmechanics.com/science/space/rockets/musk-spacex-now-has-all-the-pieces-for-reusable-rockets-15985616 |title=Musk: SpaceX Now Has "All the Pieces" For Truly Reusable Rockets |work=Popular Mechanics |last=Belfiore |first=Michael |date=September 30, 2013 |accessdate=October 17, 2013}}</ref>
This second EDL test took place during the [[SpaceX CRS-3|third cargo resupply mission]] for NASA in April 2014. SpaceX attached [[Launch vehicle landing gear|landing legs]] to the first stage, decelerated the stage through atmospheric re-entry and attempted a simulated landing over water, following the separation of the second stage carrying the Dragon capsule to the ISS. The first stage was slowed down sufficiently to perform a soft touchdown over the Atlantic Ocean.<ref name="ut20140419"> {{cite news |url=http://www.universetoday.com/111377/spacex-makes-strides-towards-1st-stage-falcon-rocket-recovery-during-space-station-launch/ |title=SpaceX Makes Strides Towards 1st Stage Falcon Rocket Recovery during Space Station Launch |work=Universe Today |last=Kremer |first=Ken |date=April 19, 2014 |accessdate=April 19, 2014 }}</ref><ref name=dn20140224> {{cite news |last=Klotz |first=Irene |title=SpaceX Falcon Rocket to Test Landing Legs |url=http://news.discovery.com/space/private-spaceflight/spacex-falcon-rocket-to-test-precision-landing-legs-140224.htm |accessdate=February 25, 2014 |newspaper=Discovery News |date=February 24, 2014 }}</ref> SpaceX announced in February 2014 that they intended to continue over-water tests of the first stage until mastering precision control of the vehicle from hypersonic speed all the way through subsonic regimes.<ref name="dn20140224"/>
[[#Landing attempts|Subsequent tests]], starting with the [[CRS-5]] mission in January 2015, attempted to land the first stage on an [[autonomous spaceport drone ship]] stationed off the Florida coastline or in the Pacific Ocean depending on launch site.<ref name="nsf20141124"> {{cite web|last1=Bergin|first1=Chris|title=SpaceX’s Autonomous Spaceport Drone Ship ready for action|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2014/11/spacex-autonomous-spaceport-drone-ship/|website=NASASpaceFlight|accessdate=April 23, 2015|date=November 24, 2014}}</ref> The ships were used for six landing attempts, two of which succeeded in April and May 2016. Meanwhile, the [[#Flight 20: first landing on ground pad|first attempt to land on solid ground]] at Cape Canaveral occurred on December 21, 2015, and succeeded flawlessly.
== Post-mission test plan == [[File:Falcon 9 Flight 13 infrared video of first stage propulsive descent.ogv|thumb|right|thumbtime=0:1:28|Thermal imaging of the controlled-descent test from stage separation onward, on [[Falcon 9 flight 13]], September 21, 2014. Footage shows the first stage maneuvering out of the second stage plume; coasting near peak altitude of approximately {{convert|140|km|sp=us|abbr=on}}; performing a boost-back burn to limit downrange distance; controlled ballistic descent; and reentry burn from approximately {{convert|70|km|sp=us|abbr=on}} to {{convert| 40|km|sp=us|abbr=on}} altitude. Landing burn is not visible, as clouds obscured the infrared imaging at low altitude.]]
The post-mission Falcon 9 test plan for the earliest flight tests called for the first stage to perform a retro-propulsion burn in the upper atmosphere to slow it down and put it on a descent [[External ballistics|ballistic trajectory]] to its target landing location, followed by a second burn in the lower atmosphere before the first stage reached the water.<ref name="pa20130910">{{cite news |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2013/09/10/spacex-launch-license/ |title=A Preview of Falcon 9′s Flight From Vandenberg |work=Parabolic Arc |last=Messier |first=Doug |date=September 10, 2013 |accessdate=September 11, 2013}}</ref> SpaceX announced in March 2013 that it intended to conduct such tests on Falcon 9 v1.1 launch vehicles and would "continue doing such tests until they can do a return to the launch site and a powered landing". The company said it expected several failures before it could land the vehicle successfully.<ref name=dn20140224/><ref name=nsf20140228>{{cite news |last=Bergin |first=Chris |title=SpaceX outlines CRS-3 landing legs plan toward first stage recovery ambitions |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2014/02/spacex-crs-3-landing-legs-plan-first-stage-recovery-ambitions/ |accessdate=May 10, 2014 |newspaper=NASAspaceflight.com |date=February 28, 2014}}</ref>
In detailed information disclosed in the Falcon 9 flight 6 [[launch license]] for the [[CASSIOPE]] mission, SpaceX said it would fire three of the nine [[Merlin 1D]] engines initially to slow the horizontal velocity of the rocket and begin the attempt at a controlled descent.<ref name="pa20130910"/> Then, shortly before hitting the ocean, one engine would be relighted in an attempt to reduce the stage's speed so that it could be recovered. {{As of|2013|9}}, SpaceX said the experiment had approximately a ten percent chance of success.<ref name="sn20130906">{{cite news |url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/launch-report/37094musk-says-spacex-being-%E2%80%9Cextremely-paranoid%E2%80%9D-as-it-readies-for-falcon-9%E2%80%99s |title=Musk Says SpaceX Being "Extremely Paranoid" as It Readies for Falcon 9's California Debut |work=Space News |last=Klotz |first=Irene |date=September 6, 2013 |accessdate=September 13, 2013}}</ref>
SpaceX did not perform controlled-descent tests on all Falcon 9 v1.1 flights, as payloads going to [[geostationary transfer orbit|GTO]] did not leave enough fuel margin.<ref name=sn20131127>{{cite news |url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/launch-report/38374why-the-world%E2%80%99s-2nd-largest-satellite-fleet-operator-agreed-to-be-spacex |title=Why the World's 2nd Largest Satellite Fleet Operator Agreed To Be SpaceX's 1st Customer for a Launch to Geo |work=Space News |last=de Selding |first=Peter B. |date=November 27, 2013 |accessdate=November 28, 2013}}</ref> In September 2013, SpaceX announced that the [[SpaceX CRS-3|CRS-3]] mission of April 2014 (fourth flight of Falcon 9 v1.1)<ref name=gizmag20140418> {{cite web |url=http://www.gizmag.com/crs-3-launch-spacex/31671/ |title=Fourth time lucky for SpaceX's CRS-3 Dragon launch |work=Gizmag |first=David |last=Szondy |date=April 18, 2014 |accessdate=November 27, 2014}}</ref> would be the second test of the descent test profile.<ref name="bbc20130930" />
Whereas the early tests restarted the engines only twice, by the fourth flight test, in September 2014, SpaceX was reigniting the engines three times to accomplish its EDL test objectives (although only three of the nine engines were used): a boost-back burn, a reentry burn, and a landing burn. The boost-back burn limits [[downrange]] translation of the used stage; the reentry burn (from approximately {{convert|70|to|40|km|sp=us|abbr=on}} altitude) is used to control the descent and deceleration profile at [[atmospheric interface]]; and the landing burn completes the deceleration from [[terminal velocity]] to zero at the landing surface.<ref name=nasa20141017/><ref name=aw20141016/>
== Test flights ==
=== Ocean touchdown attempts ===
==== Flight 6 ==== The first [[EDL (rocketry)|propulsive reentry, descent, and ocean-surface touchdown]] test occurred on September 29, 2013, on [[Falcon 9 flight 6]], the maiden launch of the [[Falcon 9 v1.1|Falcon 9 rocket, version v1.1]]. After the three-minute boost phase and separation of the second stage with the [[CASSIOPE]] and [[nanosat]] payloads, the rocket's first stage was [[Attitude control|reoriented]] backwards and three of the nine [[Merlin 1D]] engines were reignited at high altitude to initiate a deceleration and controlled descent trajectory to the surface of the ocean. The first phase of the test "worked well and the first stage re-entered safely".<ref name="pa20130930">{{cite news |url=http://www.parabolicarc.com/2013/09/29/falcon-9-launch-payloads-orbit-vandenberg/ |title=Falcon 9 Launches Payloads into Orbit From Vandenberg |work=Parabolic Arc |last=Messier |first=Doug |date=September 29, 2013 |accessdate=September 30, 2013}}</ref> However, the stage began to roll because of aerodynamic forces during the atmospheric descent and the roll rate exceeded the capabilities of the first stage [[attitude control system]] (ACS) to [[Null (physics)|null it out]]. The fuel in the tanks "centrifuged" to the outside of the tank and the single engine involved in the low-altitude deceleration maneuver shut down. SpaceX was able to retrieve some first-stage debris from the ocean.<ref name="bbc20130930" /><ref name="pa20130930" /> The company did not expect to recover the first stage on this flight,<ref name=sdc20131017/> nor on the first several powered-descent tests, as predicted in their March 2013 announcement.<ref name="pa20130328-2"/>
This first experimental descent was considered successful, achieving substantial test milestones and collecting a great deal of engineering data, despite losing the stage into the ocean.<ref name=sdc20131017>{{cite news |url=http://www.space.com/23230-spacex-falcon9-reusable-rocket-milestone.html |title=SpaceX Hit Huge Reusable Rocket Milestone with Falcon 9 Test |work=Space.com |last=Wall |first=Mike |date=October 17, 2013 |accessdate=December 5, 2013}}</ref> SpaceX tested a large amount of new technology on this flight, and, combining those results with the advances made on the Grasshopper demonstrator, the company now believed it had "all the pieces of the puzzle".<ref name=pm20130930/><ref name=sdc20131017/><ref name="th20131025">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2013/oct/25/things-learned-tesla-elon-musk-electric-car |title=12 interesting things we learned from Tesla's Elon Musk this week |work=The Guardian |first=Adam |last=Vaughan |date=October 25, 2013 |accessdate=October 26, 2013 |quote=We managed to re-enter the atmosphere, not break up like we normally do, and get all way down to sea level.}}</ref>
==== Flight 9 ==== The second test of controlled-descent hardware and software on the first stage [[Falcon 9 flight 9|occurred on April 8, 2014]],<ref name="ut20140419" /> and became the first successful controlled ocean soft touchdown of a liquid-rocket-engine orbital first stage.<ref name=mit20140422> {{cite news |last=Belfiore |first=Michael |title=SpaceX Brings a Booster Safely Back to Earth |url=http://www.technologyreview.com/news/526806/spacex-brings-a-booster-safely-back-to-earth/ |accessdate=April 25, 2014 |newspaper=MIT Technology Review |date=April 22, 2014}}</ref><ref name=bi20141125> {{cite news |last1=Orwig |first1=Jessica |title=Elon Musk Just Unveiled A Game-Changing Ocean Landing Pad For His Reusable Rockets |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musk-rockets-that-land-at-sea-2014-11 |accessdate=December 11, 2014 |work=Business Insider |date=November 25, 2014 |quote=''The first successful "soft landing" of a Falcon 9 rocket happened in April of this year''}}</ref> The first stage included landing legs for the first time which were extended to simulate a landing upon touchdown, and the test utilized more powerful gaseous Nitrogen [[Reaction control system|control thrusters]] to control the aerodynamic-induced rotation that had occurred on the first test flight. The first stage successfully approached the water surface with no spin and at zero vertical velocity, as designed.<ref name=dn20140224/><ref name=aw20140428a>{{cite news |last=Norris |first=Guy |title=SpaceX Plans For Multiple Reusable first stage Tests |url=http://aviationweek.com/space/spacex-plans-multiple-reusable-booster-tests |accessdate=May 17, 2014 |newspaper=Aviation Week |date=April 28, 2014 |quote=The April 17 F9R Dev 1 flight, which lasted under 1 min., was the first vertical landing test of a production-representative recoverable Falcon 9 v1.1 first stage, while the April 18 cargo flight to the ISS was the first opportunity for SpaceX to evaluate the design of foldable landing legs and upgraded thrusters that control the stage during its initial descent.}}</ref>
During the second test, the first stage was traveling at a velocity of {{convert|10|Mach|262000|sigfig=3}}<ref name=aw20140428a/> at an altitude of {{convert|80|km|ft|sp=us}}<ref name=crs3PressKit201403>{{cite web |title=SpaceX CRS-3 Mission Press Kit: Cargo Resupply Services Mission |url=http://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/files/SpaceXCRS-3_PressKit_FINAL.pdf |publisher=NASA |accessdate=March 15, 2014 |date=March 2014}}</ref> at the time of the high-altitude turn-around maneuver, followed by ignition of three of the nine main engines for the initial deceleration and placement onto its descent trajectory.<ref name=mtr20140313/> The "first stage executed a good re-entry burn and was able to stabilize itself on the way down. ... [The] landing in [the] Atlantic [ocean] was good! ... Flight computers continued transmitting [telemetry data] for 8 seconds after reaching the water" and stopped only after the first stage went horizontal.<ref name=nbc20140418>{{cite news |last=Boyle |first=Alan |title=Cargo Launch and Rocket Test Add Up to 'Happy Day' for SpaceX |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/science/space/cargo-launch-rocket-test-add-happy-day-spacex-n84266 |accessdate=April 20, 2014 |newspaper=NBC News |date=April 18, 2014}}</ref>
The major modifications for the second first stage controlled-descent test flight included changes to both the reentry burn and the landing burn as well as adding increased [[attitude control system]] (ACS) capabilities.<ref name=tss20140321b>{{cite AV media |people=Gwynne Shotwell |date=March 21, 2014 |title=Broadcast 2212: Special Edition, interview with Gwynne Shotwell |medium=audio file |url=http://archived.thespaceshow.com/shows/2212-BWB-2014-03-21.mp3 |accessdate=March 22, 2014 |archiveurl=http://www.thespaceshow.com/detail.asp?q=2212<!-- link to the description page on the TSS website with a link to listen to the episode --> |archivedate=March 22, 2014 |format=mp3 |time=51;50–52;55 |publisher=The Space Show |id=2212 |quote= }}</ref>
SpaceX had projected a low probability of stage recovery following the flight test due to complexity of the test sequence and the large number of steps that would need to be carried out perfectly.<ref name=dn20140224/> The company was careful to label the entire flight test as "an experiment".<ref name=sfn20140414>{{cite news |last=Clark |first=Stephen |title=Recovery crews positioned to retrieve Falcon 9 first stage |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/falcon9/009/140414recovery/ |accessdate=April 14, 2014 |newspaper=Spaceflight Now |date=April 14, 2014}}</ref> In a press conference at the [[National Press Club (United States)|National Press Club]] on April 25, Elon Musk said that the first stage achieved a soft touchdown on the ocean but due to rough seas, the stage was destroyed.<ref name="bbc20140425">{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-27166780 |title=SpaceX rocket stage in 'soft landing' |work=BBC News |first=Jonathan |last=Amos |date=April 25, 2014 |accessdate=April 26, 2014}}</ref><ref name="pressclub20140425">{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a_rnija1nOA |title=SpaceX Press Conference at the National Press Club |work=YouTube.com |publisher=National Press Club |first=Elon |last=Musk |date=April 25, 2014 |accessdate=April 26, 2014}}</ref>
==== Flight 10 ==== The third test flight of a returned first stage was July 14, 2014, on [[Falcon 9 flight 10]]. Whereas the previous test reached a target landing area some hundreds of kilometers off the Florida coast, this flight aimed for a boost-back trajectory that would attempt the ocean touchdown much nearer the coast, and closer to the original launch location at Cape Canaveral. Following the third controlled-descent test flight, SpaceX expressed confidence in their ability to successfully land in the future on a "[[floating launch platform|floating launch pad]] or back at the launch site and refly the rocket with no required refurbishment."<ref name=nsf20140728/>
Following the first stage loft of the second stage and payload on its orbital trajectory, SpaceX conducted a successful [[test flight|flight test]] on the spent first stage. The first stage successfully [[Deceleration|decelerated]] from [[hypersonic speed]] in the upper atmosphere, made a successful [[Atmospheric entry|reentry]], landing burn, and deployment of its [[launch vehicle landing gear|landing legs]], and touched down on the ocean surface. The first stage was not recovered for analysis as the hull integrity was breached, either upon touchdown or on the subsequent "tip over and body slam".<ref name=nbc20140714> {{cite news |title=SpaceX Falcon Rocket Sends Up a Six-Pack of Satellites |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/science/space/spacex-falcon-rocket-sends-six-pack-satellites-n155396 |accessdate=July 15, 2014 |publisher=NBC |date=July 14, 2014 |quote=Musk: 'Rocket first stage reentry, landing burn & leg deploy were good, but lost hull integrity right after splashdown (aka kaboom) ... Detailed review of rocket telemetry needed to tell if due to initial splashdown or subsequent tip over and body slam.'}}</ref> Results of the post-landing analysis showed that the hull integrity was lost as the {{convert|150|ft|m|adj=on|disp=flip}}-tall first stage fell horizontally, as planned, onto the ocean surface following the landing.<ref name=nsf20140728> {{cite news |last1=Bergin |first1=Chris |title=SpaceX Roadmap building on its rocket business revolution |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2014/07/spacex-roadmap-rocket-business-revolution/ |accessdate=July 28, 2014 |publisher=NASAspaceflight |date=July 28, 2014 |quote=''At this point, we are highly confident of being able to land successfully on a floating launch pad or back at the launch site and refly the rocket with no required refurbishment''}}</ref>
==== Flight 13 ==== [[File:SupersonicRetropropulsion-Falcon9 first stage on SpaceX CRS4, 21 September 2014.jpg|thumb|Infrared thermal imagery of Falcon 9 SpaceX CRS-4 launch. The larger image was captured shortly after second stage separation from the first stage: the top of the first stage appears as a dim dot below the larger plume. In the inset, the restarted first stage engines power the stage.]]
The fourth test flight of a returned first stage, with a planned ocean touchdown, occurred on [[SpaceX CRS-4|Falcon 9 flight 13]] which was launched on September 21, 2014.<ref name=sn20140721/> and the first stage flew a profile approaching a zero-velocity at zero-altitude simulated landing on the sea surface.<ref name=aw20141016/> SpaceX made no attempt to recover the first stage, since earlier tests had confirmed that the 14-[[Storey|story]]<!-- use US spelling: story, not storey --> tall first stage would not survive the tip-over event into the sea. The booster did run out of liquid oxygen.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bvim4rsNHkQ&t=32s</ref>
One month later, detailed [[thermal imaging]] infrared sensor data and video were released of the controlled-descent test. The data was collected by NASA in a joint arrangement with SpaceX as part of research on [[supersonic retropropulsion|retropropulsive deceleration technologies]] in order to develop new approaches to [[Mars]] [[atmospheric entry]]. A key problem with propulsive techniques is handling the [[Fluid dynamics|fluid flow]] problems and [[attitude control system|attitude control]] of the descent vehicle during the supersonic retropropulsion phase of the entry and deceleration. All phases of the night-time flight test on the first stage were successfully imaged except for the final landing burn, as that occurred below the clouds where the [[Infrared signature|IR data]] was not visible.<ref name=aw20141016> {{cite news|last1=Morring |first1=Frank, Jr. |title=NASA, SpaceX Share Data On Supersonic Retropropulsion : Data-sharing deal will help SpaceX land Falcon 9 on Earth and NASA put humans on Mars |url=http://aviationweek.com/space/nasa-spacex-share-data-supersonic-retropropulsion |accessdate=March 28, 2015 |work=Aviation Week |date=October 20, 2014 |quote=''[The] partnership between NASA and SpaceX is giving the U.S. space agency an early look at what it would take to land multi-ton habitats and supply caches on Mars for human explorers, while providing sophisticated infrared (IR) imagery to help the spacecraft company develop a reusable launch vehicle. After multiple attempts, airborne NASA and U.S. Navy IR tracking cameras ... captured a SpaceX Falcon 9 in flight as its first stage [fell] back toward Earth shortly after second-stage ignition and then reignit[ed] to lower the stage toward a propulsive "zero-velocity, zero-altitude" touchdown on the sea surface.'' |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141027133828/http://aviationweek.com/space/nasa-spacex-share-data-supersonic-retropropulsion |archivedate=October 27, 2014 }}</ref> The research team is particularly interested in the {{convert|70|-|40|km|adj=on|sp=us}} altitude range of the SpaceX "reentry burn" on the Falcon 9 Earth-entry tests as this is the "powered flight through the Mars-relevant retropulsion regime" that models Mars entry and descent conditions.<ref name=nasa20141017> {{cite web |title=New Commercial Rocket Descent Data May Help NASA with Future Mars Landings, no. 14-287 |url=http://www.nasa.gov/press/2014/october/new-commercial-rocket-descent-data-may-help-nasa-with-future-mars-landings/index.html#.VEGN4BbdeI0 |publisher=NASA |accessdate=October 19, 2014 |date=October 17, 2014}}</ref>
==== Flight 15 ==== [[File:Falcon 9 1st stage re-entry with grid fins; DSCOVR mission (16849254595).png|thumb|Falcon 9 flight 15 first stage re-entry with grid fins. Onboard camera view]] SpaceX had planned to make the sixth controlled-descent test flight and second<ref name=nsf20150208/> landing attempt on their drone ship no earlier than February 11, 2015. Landing a returning rocket at sea would have been a "potentially historic rocket launch and landing", as such a feat "was unheard of" five years earlier.<ref name=nsf20150208> {{cite news |last1=Graham |first1=William |title=SpaceX Falcon 9 ready for DSCOVR mission |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/02/spacex-falcon-9-dscovr-mission/ |accessdate=February 8, 2015 |work=NASASpaceFlight.com |date=February 8, 2015 <!-- this nsf20150208 article was updated on February 10, 2015, apparently by the editors of NSF, and left at the same old URL prior to the 2nd launch attempt scheduled for Feb 10, and oddly the article title changed also; I am leaving this citation as the 8Feb access, with the 8Feb title, as that fully supports the statements made here in wiki-prose. -->}}</ref><ref name=bi20150205> {{cite news |last1=Orwig |first1=Jessica |title=SpaceX will attempt a potentially historic rocket launch and landing this weekend |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/spacex-falcon9-ocean-landing-test-live-2015-2 |accessdate=February 7, 2015 |work=Business Insider |date=February 5, 2015}}</ref><ref name=nsf20150116/>
According to regulatory paperwork filed in 2014, SpaceX plans had called for the sixth test flight to occur on a [[Falcon 9 flight 15|late January 2015 launch attempt]]. However, after the completion of the fifth test flight, and with some damage being incurred by the drone ship in the botched landing, it was not clear whether the sixth test would still be feasible only a few weeks later.<ref name=sfn20150110> {{cite news |last1=Clark |first1=Stephen |title=Dragon successfully launched, rocket recovery demo crash lands |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/2015/01/10/dragon-successfully-launched-rocket-recovery-demo-crash-lands/ |accessdate=January 10, 2015 |work=Spaceflight Now |date=January 10, 2015}}</ref> This issue was resolved within days of the ship's return to Jacksonville, and by January 15, SpaceX was unambiguous about its plans to attempt a landing of the first stage following the boost phase of the [[Deep Space Climate Observatory]] mission.<ref name=nsf20150116> {{cite news |last1=Bergin |first1=Chris |title=DSCOVR and Recover: SpaceX chase the cigar with next Falcon 9 mission |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/01/dscovr-recover-spacex-chase-cigar-falcon-9-mission/ |accessdate=January 17, 2015 |work=NASASpaceFlight.com |date=January 16, 2015}}</ref>
However, in a statement by SpaceX, the drone ship was in conditions "with waves reaching up to three stories in height crashing over the decks". Additionally, one of the four thrusters that keep the barge in a constant position had malfunctioned, making station-keeping difficult. For these reasons, the post-launch flight test did not involve the barge, but instead attempted a soft touchdown over water.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wall |first1=Mike |title=SpaceX Won't Try Rocket Landing on Drone Ship After Satellite Launch Today |url=http://www.space.com/28528-spacex-launch-moon-blackout.html |website=Space.com |accessdate=February 11, 2015 |date=February 11, 2015}}</ref>
The test was successful, and the first stage of the Falcon 9 landed "nicely vertical" with an accuracy of 10 meters from the target location in the ocean.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hull |first1=Dana |title=SpaceX Launches Satellite as Rocket Recovery Is Scrapped |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-02-11/spacex-drops-bid-to-land-rocket-booster-on-ship-amid-rough-seas |website=Bloomberg |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=February 12, 2015 |date=February 11, 2015}}</ref>
Therefore, this test represented the fifth ocean touchdown, and the sixth overall Falcon 9 first stage controlled-descent test.
====Flight 46 ====
====Flight 48 ====
=== Landing attempts === [[File:Falcon 9 First Stage Reusability Graphic.jpg|thumb|upright=2|Depiction of Falcon 9 landing trajectory in floating-platform recovery tests]] {{As of|2017|12|15}},<!-- UPDATE after each flight --> SpaceX has attempted 25 <!-- UPDATE after each flight --> landings of a first stage on a solid surface, 20 <!-- UPDATE after each flight --> of which have succeeded.
In July 2014, SpaceX announced that the fifth and sixth controlled-descent test flights would attempt to land on a solid surface, merging the lessons from the high-altitude [[flight envelope|envelope expansion]] of the first four controlled-descent flights over water with the low-altitude lessons of the [[F9R Dev]] testing in Texas.<ref name=sn20140721> {{cite news |last1=Berger |first1=Brian |title=SpaceX Releases Footage of Falcon 9 First-stage Splashdown |url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/launch-report/41350spacex-releases-footage-of-falcon-9-first-stage-splashdown |accessdate=July 23, 2014 |publisher=SpaceNews |date=July 21, 2014}}</ref> At that time, the "solid surface" was not further described, and was later revealed to be a seafaring barge dubbed an [[autonomous spaceport drone ship]].
Many of the test objectives were achieved on the first attempt, including bringing the stage to the specific location of the floating platform and collecting a large amount of test data with the first use of [[grid fin]] control surfaces for more precise reentry positioning. However the touchdown on the corner of the barge was a [[hard landing]] and most of the rocket body fell into the ocean and sank; SpaceX published a short clip of the crash.<ref name="flight14-vine" /> It would take four more attempts to achieve the first barge landing at sea on [[#Flight 23: first landing on drone ship|flight 23]].<ref name="flight23-natgeo" /> Meanwhile, ground landing succeeded on the first attempt with [[#Flight 20: first landing on ground pad|flight 20]] on December 21, 2015.<ref name="flight20-space.com" />
In October 2014, SpaceX clarified that the "solid surface" would be a [[Floating landing platform|floating platform]] constructed from a barge in Louisiana, and confirmed that they would attempt to land the first stage of the [[Falcon 9 flight 14|fourteenth Falcon 9 flight]] on the platform.<ref name=sn20141024> {{cite news |last1=Foust |first1=Jeff |title=Next Falcon 9 Launch Could See First-stage Platform Landing |url=http://www.spacenews.com/article/launch-report/42305next-falcon-9-launch-could-see-first-stage-platform-landing |accessdate=October 25, 2014 |work=Space News |date=October 25, 2014}}</ref><!-- LINK to MIT conference video primary source: [http://webcast.amps.ms.mit.edu/fall2014/AeroAstro/index-Fri-PM.html MIT AeroAstro Centennial Symposium], October 24, 2014 --> For the landing to succeed, the {{convert|60|ft|m|disp=flip|abbr=on|adj=on}}-wide span of the rocket [[launch vehicle landing gear|landing legs]] must not only land within the {{convert|170|ft|m|disp=flip|abbr=on|adj=on}}-wide barge deck, but would need to also deal with [[Swell (ocean)|ocean swell]] and [[Dilution of precision (GPS)|GPS errors]].<ref name=nsf20141117/> In late November, SpaceX revealed that the landing barge would be capable of [[Autonomous robot|autonomous operation]] and would not need to be anchored or moored;<ref name=nsf20141124 /> it was hence called an [[autonomous spaceport drone ship]]. {{As of|2015|1}} three of these ships had been built, two of which were operational.<ref name=musk20150123>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/558703223909781505 |title=West Coast droneship under construction... |publisher=Twitter.com |first=Elon |last=Musk |date=23 January 2015}}</ref>
==== Flight 14 ==== This fifth controlled-descent test flight was anticipated by the specialized press as a historic core return attempt.<ref name=nsf20150105> {{cite news |last1=Graham |first1=William |title=SpaceX set for Dragon CRS-5 launch and historic core return attempt |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/01/spacex-dragon-crs-5-launch-historic-core-return/ |accessdate=January 6, 2015 |work=NASASpaceFlight.com |date=January 5, 2015 |quote=''While the Falcon 9’s second stage continues to orbit with the Dragon spacecraft, its first stage will execute a series of maneuvers which SpaceX hope will culminate in a successful landing atop a floating platform off the coast of Florida. The demonstration follows successful tests during two previous launches where the first stage has been guided to a controlled water landing, however the stage has not been recoverable on either previous attempt. ... Achieving a precision landing on a floating platform is an important milestone for SpaceX as they attempt to demonstrate their planned flyback recovery of the first stage of the Falcon 9.''}}</ref> It incorporated for the first time in an orbital mission the [[grid fin]] [[Flight control surfaces|aerodynamic control surfaces]] that had previously been tested only during a low-altitude, low-speed test with the [[F9R Dev1]] prototype vehicle in early 2014. The addition of grid fins, with continuation of the control authority obtained from gimbaling the engines as on previous test flights, was projected to improve the [[landing ellipse|landing accuracy]] to {{convert|10|m|sp=us|abbr=on}}, a thousand-fold improvement over the four previous test flights which landed within {{convert|10|km|sp=us|abbr=on}} of their target coordinates.<ref name=sx20141216> {{cite web |title=X MARKS THE SPOT: FALCON 9 ATTEMPTS OCEAN PLATFORM LANDING |url=http://www.spacex.com/news/2014/12/16/x-marks-spot-falcon-9-attempts-ocean-platform-landing |publisher=SpaceX |accessdate=December 17, 2014 |date=December 16, 2014 |quote=A key upgrade to enable precision targeting of the Falcon 9 all the way to touchdown is the addition of four hypersonic grid fins placed in an X-wing configuration around the vehicle, stowed on ascent and deployed on reentry to control the stage's lift vector. Each fin moves independently for roll, pitch and yaw, and combined with the engine gimbaling, will allow for precision landing – first on the autonomous spaceport drone ship, and eventually on land. }}</ref> Prior to the flight, SpaceX projected that the likelihood of success on the first try was 50 percent or less.<ref name=nsf20141117> {{cite news |last1=Bergin |first1=Chris |title=Pad 39A – SpaceX laying the groundwork for Falcon Heavy debut |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2014/11/pad-39a-spacex-groundwork-falcon-heavy-debut/ |accessdate=November 21, 2014 |work=NASA SpaceFlight |date=November 18, 2014}}</ref>
The first test flight for this new hardware occurred on January 10, 2015, on the [[SpaceX CRS-5|CRS-5 mission]] for NASA. The controlled-descent flight started approximately three minutes after launch, following the second stage separation event,<ref name=nsf20150105/> when the first stage was approximately {{convert|80|km|abbr=on}} high and moving at a velocity of {{convert|10|Mach|262000|sigfig=2}}.<ref name=nasa201412> {{cite web |title=SpaceX CRS-% Mission: Cargo Resupply Services |url=http://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/files/SpaceX_NASA_CRS-5_PressKit.pdf |website=nasa.gov |publisher=NASA |accessdate=January 17, 2015 |date=December 2014 |quote=''Approximately 157 seconds into flight, the first-stage engines are shut down, an event known as main-engine cutoff, or MECO. At this point, Falcon 9 is 80 kilometers (50 miles) high, traveling at 10 times the speed of sound.''}}</ref>
The SpaceX webcast indicated that the boostback burn and reentry burns for the descending first stage occurred, and that the descending rocket then went "below the horizon," as expected, which eliminated the live telemetry signal, so that the [[retropropulsive landing]] attempt was not shown live. Shortly thereafter, SpaceX released information that the rocket did get to the drone ship as planned, but "landed hard ... Ship itself is fine. Some of the support equipment on the deck will need to be replaced."<ref name="musk-tweet-20150110-1"> {{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |author-link=Elon Musk |number=553855109114101760 |date=January 10, 2015 |access-date=January 10, 2015 |title=Rocket made it to drone spaceport ship, but landed hard. Close, but no cigar this time. Bodes well for the future tho. }}</ref><ref name="musk-tweet-20150110-2"> {{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |author-link=Elon Musk |number=553856479590359040 |date=January 10, 2015 |access-date=January 10, 2015 |title=Ship itself is fine. Some of the support equipment on the deck will need to be replaced... }}</ref><ref name="musk-tweet-20150110-3"> {{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |author-link=Elon Musk |number=553857574005915648 |date=January 10, 2015 |access-date=January 10, 2015 |title=Didn't get good landing/impact video. Pitch dark and foggy. Will piece it together from telemetry and ... actual pieces. }}</ref> Musk later elaborated that the rocket's flight-control surfaces had exhausted their supply of hydraulic fluid prior to impact.<ref name="musk-tweet-20150110-4"> {{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |author-link=Elon Musk |number=553963793056030721 |date=January 10, 2015 |access-date=January 13, 2015 |title=Grid fins worked extremely well from hypersonic velocity to subsonic, but ran out of hydraulic fluid right before landing. }}</ref> Musk posted photos of the impact while talking to [[John Carmack]] on Twitter. SpaceX later released a video of the impact on [[Vine (service)|Vine]].<ref name="flight14-vine">{{cite web |url=https://vine.co/v/OjqeYWWpVWK |title=Close, but no cigar. This time. |author=[[SpaceX]] |work= [[Vine (service)|Vine]] |date=January 16, 2015 |access-date=May 8, 2016 }}</ref>
==== Flight 17 ==== A seventh test flight of the first stage controlled-descent profile occurred on April 14, 2015, on Falcon 9 flight 17, which carried [[CRS-6]] to the [[International Space Station]]. This was SpaceX's second attempt to land on a floating platform. The first stage was fitted with grid fins and landing legs to facilitate the post-mission test.
An early report from Elon Musk suggested that the first stage made a hard landing on the drone ship.<ref name="musk-tweet-20150415"> {{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |author-link=Elon Musk |number=588076749562318849 |date=April 14, 2015 |access-date=May 8, 2016 |title=Ascent successful. Dragon enroute to Space Station. Rocket landed on droneship, but too hard for survival. }}</ref> Musk later clarified that the [[bipropellant]] valve was stuck, and therefore the control system could not react rapidly enough for a successful landing.<ref name=aw20150416> {{cite web |url=http://aviationweek.com/space/spacex-checks-throttle-valve-after-flawed-falcon-9-recovery-attempt |title=SpaceX Checks Throttle Valve After Flawed Falcon 9 Recovery Attempt |author=Guy Norris |date=April 16, 2015 }}</ref> On April 15, SpaceX released a video of the terminal phase of the descent, the landing, the tip over, and the resulting [[deflagration]] as the stage broke up on the deck of the ASDS.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BhMSzC1crr0 CRS-6 First Stage Landing], SpaceX, April 15, 2015.</ref>
==== Flight 20: first landing on ground pad {{Anchor|Flight 20}} ====
The first attempt to land the first stage of Falcon 9 on a ground pad near the launch site occurred on [[Falcon 9 flight 20|flight 20]], the maiden flight of the [[Falcon 9 Full Thrust]] version, on the evening of December 21, 2015. The landing was successful and the first stage was recovered.<ref name="flight20-space.com"> {{cite news |url=http://www.space.com/31420-spacex-rocket-landing-success.html |title=Wow! SpaceX Lands Orbital Rocket Successfully in Historic First |work=[[Space.com]] |first=Mike |last=Wall |date=December 21, 2015 |access-date=May 8, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="flight20-tweet"> {{cite tweet |user=SpaceX |author-link=SpaceX |number=679114269485436928 |date=December 22, 2015 |access-date=May 8, 2016 |title=The Falcon 9 first stage landing is confirmed. Second stage continuing nominally. }}</ref> This was [[Timeline of rocket and missile technology#21st century|the first time in history]] that a rocket first stage returned to Earth after propelling an orbital launch mission and achieved a controlled [[VTVL|vertical landing]].
SpaceX applied to the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] (FAA) US regulatory authority to perform its eighth booster controlled-descent test culminating with a landing attempt at the ''[[SpaceX Landing Zone 1|Landing Zone 1]]'' facility (formerly [[Launch Complex 13]]) that SpaceX had recently built at [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]].<ref name="ft201511201">{{cite news |last1=Dean|first1=James |title=SpacexSpaceX wants to land next first stage at Cape Canaveral |url=http://www.floridatoday.com/story/tech/science/space/spacex/2015/12/01/spacex-wants-land-next-first-stage-cape-canaveral/76576142/ |accessdate=December 2, 2015 |work=Florida Today |date=2015-12-01 }}</ref> The FAA cleared SpaceX to attempt this landing after assessing that it would inflict minimal damage on the environment.<ref name="bi20151219">{{cite web|last1=Orwig|first1=Jessica|title=SpaceX will attempt a potentially historic rocket landing like never before this weekend|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/spacex-attempts-rocket-landing-on-land-on-saturday-2015-12|website=Business Insider|accessdate=December 19, 2015|date=December 19, 2015}}</ref><ref name="os20151220">{{cite news |title=SpaceX aims for Sunday launch and ground landing |url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/news/space/go-for-launch/os-spacex-engine-testing-sunday-launch-20151218-post.html |work=Orlando Sentinel |date=2015-12-20 |accessdate=2015-12-20 }}</ref> Additionally, NASA planned to close<!-- the past tense form "closed" is not supported by either of the 18 Dec sources provided, which were from before the launch and test flight sequence --> the [[NASA Causeway]] near the launch and landing site and significantly increase the size of exclusion zones during the launch and landing attempt.<ref name="sn20151218">{{cite web|last1=Foust|first1=Jeff|title=FAA Moves Closer to Approving Falcon 9 Landings at Cape Canaveral|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/12/spacex-static-fire-falcon-9-og-2-rtf/|website=SpaceNews|accessdate=December 19, 2015|date=December 18, 2015}}</ref><ref name="nsf20151218">{{cite web|last1=Bergin|first1=Chris|title=SpaceX Falcon 9 Static Fires ahead of OG2 RTF mission|url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/12/spacex-static-fire-falcon-9-og-2-rtf/|website=NASASpaceFlight|accessdate=December 19, 2015|date=December 18, 2015}}</ref>{{update after|2016|2|1}} Both options to attempt landing on the ground pad or on the drone ship at sea remained open until the day of the launch. The final decision to return the booster to Cape Canaveral was made based on a number of factors, including weather at the potential landing sites.{{citation needed|date=May 2016}}
Flight 20 took off at 20:29 [[Eastern Standard Time (North America)|EST]] on December 21, 2015 (01:29 [[UTC]] on December 22, 2015). About 9 minutes and 45 seconds later, the first stage landed vertically on the pad.<ref name="flight20-space.com" /><ref name="flight20-tweet" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3G8GJQumBFs|title=SpaceX Falcon 9 1st Successful Launch/Landing on Target|first=|last=ShantiUniverse|date=December 21, 2015|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
SpaceX does not plan to fly the Falcon 9 flight 20 first stage again.<ref>{{cite web |title = SpaceX’s 'reusable' Falcon 9 rocket won’t fly again, Elon Musk says |url = https://www.theverge.com/2015/12/21/10642028/spacex-falcon-9-landing-elon-musk-wont-fly |website = The Verge |accessdate = 2015-12-26 |date = 2015-12-21 |last = O'Kane |first = Sean}}</ref> Rather, the rocket was inspected and moved back to the launch pad a few miles north to perform a [[static fire]] test. After the hot fire test, the vehicle was evaluated in detail by SpaceX to assess capabilities for reflight of the launch vehicle design after future landings.
On December 31, SpaceX announced that no damage had been found on the stage and that it was ready to fire again.<ref name=sn20160103> {{cite news |title=SpaceX Reports No Damage to Falcon 9 First Stage After Landing |url=http://spacenews.com/spacex-reports-no-damage-to-falcon-9-first-stage-after-landing/ |date=January 3, 2016 |accessdate=2016-01-04 }}</ref><ref name="musk-tweet-20151231"> {{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |author-link=Elon Musk |number=682717803166695425 |date=December 31, 2015 |access-date=January 2, 2016 |title=Falcon 9 back in the hangar at Cape Canaveral. No damage found, ready to fire again. }}</ref> On January 15, 2016, SpaceX conducted the static fire test on the recovered booster and reported a good overall outcome, except for some thrust fluctuations in one of the outer engines (engine 9). Elon Musk reported that this may have been due to debris ingestion.<ref>{{cite news |title=SpaceX Tests Recovered Falcon 9 Stage and Prepares for Next Launch|url=http://spacenews.com/spacex-tests-recovered-falcon-9-stage-and-prepares-for-next-launch/ |date=January 15, 2016 |accessdate=2016-01-15 }}</ref>
This booster has been on display outside of SpaceX headquarters in Hawthorne, California since August 20, 2016.
==== Flight 21 ==== [[Falcon 9 Flight 21|Flight 21]], the final launch of a [[Falcon 9 v1.1]], carried the [[Jason 3]] payload. At one point this was the first possible opportunity for an attempt to land the first stage on land,<ref name=nsf20150403> {{cite news |last1=Bergin |first1=Chris |title=SpaceX preparing for a busy season of missions and test milestones |url=http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2015/04/spacex-preparing-busy-season-missions-test-milestones/ |accessdate=April 4, 2015 |work=NASASpaceFlight.com |date=April 3, 2015}}</ref> but the launches were reordered following the loss of [[Falcon 9 flight 19]] in June 2015. Jason-3 was successfully launched on January 17, 2016, and while the first stage managed to slow down towards a soft landing, the lockout [[collet]] on one of the landing legs did not latch correctly, which caused the rocket to fall over and explode after touching down.<ref name="musk-tweet-20160117"> {{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |author-link=Elon Musk |number=688816554306191360 |date=January 17, 2016 |access-date=January 17, 2016 |title=However, that was not what prevented it being good. Touchdown speed was ok, but a leg lockout didn't latch, so it tipped over after landing. }}</ref><ref name="spacex-tweet-20160117"> {{cite tweet |user=SpaceX |author-link=SpaceX |number=688834952293519360 |date=January 17, 2016 |access-date=January 17, 2016 |title=After further data review, stage landed softly but leg 3 didn't lockout. Was within 1.3 meters of droneship center }}</ref> Elon Musk noted that ice buildup on the collet from the high-humidity launch conditions may have led to the failure of the latch.<ref> {{cite web |url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BAqirNbwEc0/ |title=Elon Musk on Instagram: Falcon lands on droneship |author=[[Elon Musk]] |work=Instagram |date=January 17, 2016 |accessdate=January 17, 2016 |quote=Falcon lands on droneship, but the lockout collet doesn't latch on one the four legs, causing it to tip over post landing. Root cause may have been ice buildup due to condensation from heavy fog at liftoff. }}</ref><ref name=gw20160117> {{cite news |last=Boyle|first=Alan |url=http://www.geekwire.com/2016/spacex-launches-jason-3-satellite-then-tries-landing-falcon-9-rocket-at-sea/ |title=SpaceX rocket launches satellite, but tips over during sea landing attempt |work=GeekWire |date=2016-01-17 |accessdate=2016-01-18 }}</ref><!-- this gw20160117 ref by veteran space journalist Alan Boyle really covers the entire rather extensive set of tweets SpaceX and Elon Musk did on 17 Jan to describe the landing and preliminary analysis of what happened. -->
==== Flight 22 ==== On March 4, 2016 the Falcon 9 flight 22 launched the {{convert|5,271|kg|round=10|abbr=on|adj=on}} heavy [[SES-9]] [[communications satellite]],<ref name=sfn20160224> {{cite news |last=Clark|first=Stephen |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/2016/02/24/falcon-9-rocket-to-give-ses-9-telecom-satellite-an-extra-boost/ |title=Falcon 9 rocket to give SES 9 telecom satellite an extra boost |work=[[Spaceflight Now]] |date=2016-02-24 |accessdate=2016-03-07}}</ref><ref name=reuters20160223> {{cite news |last=Klotz |first=Irene |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-space-spacex-ses-idUSKCN0VW2O7 |title=Satellite operator SES says interested in used SpaceX rocket |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=2016-02-23 |accessdate=2016-02-24 }}</ref> the rocket's largest payload yet targeting a [[delta-V|highly-energetic]] [[geosynchronous transfer orbit]] (GTO). Consequently, the Falcon 9 first stage followed a [[ballistic trajectory]] after separation and re-entered the atmosphere at high velocity with very little fuel to mitigate potential aerodynamic damage.
Therefore, SpaceX did not expect to successfully land its Falcon 9 booster on its sea barge, the ''[[Of Course I Still Love You]],'' positioned in the Atlantic Ocean. Elon Musk confirmed in a tweet that the landing attempt had failed.<ref name="musk-tweet-20160304">{{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |author-link=Elon Musk |number=705917924972736512 |date=March 4, 2016 |access-date=May 8, 2016 |title=Rocket landed hard on the droneship. Didn't expect this one to work (v hot reentry), but next flight has a good chance. }}</ref><ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.gizmag.com/ses-9-falcon-9-launch-unknown/42097/|title=SES-9 mission launch successful, but Falcon 9 landing less so|author=David Szondy|date=March 4, 2016|work=Gizmag|accessdate=March 4, 2016}}</ref>
==== Flight 23: first landing on a drone ship ==== {{anchor|Flight 23}} On April 8, 2016, Falcon 9 flight 23, the third flight of [[Falcon 9 Full Thrust|the full-thrust version]], delivered the [[SpaceX CRS-8]] cargo on its way to the [[International Space Station]] while the first stage conducted a boostback and re-entry maneuver over the Atlantic Ocean. Nine minutes after liftoff, [[Falcon 9 booster B1021|the booster]] landed vertically on the drone ship ''Of Course I Still Love You'', {{convert|300|km|abbr=on}} from the Florida coastline, achieving a long-sought-after milestone for the [[SpaceX reusable launch system development program|SpaceX reusability development program]].<ref name="flight23-natgeo"> {{cite news |url=http://phenomena.nationalgeographic.com/2016/04/08/spacex-rocket-makes-spectacular-landing-on-drone-ship/ |title=SpaceX Rocket Makes Spectacular Landing on Drone Ship |magazine=[[National Geographic (magazine)|National Geographic]] |first=Nadia |last=Drake |date=April 8, 2016 |accessdate=April 8, 2016 |quote=To space and back, in less than nine minutes? Hello, future. }}</ref>
This stage, serial number [[B1021]], was refurbished and flown again in March 2017 for the [[SES-10]] mission, setting another milestone in the development of reusable rockets.
==== Flight 24: first return from GTO mission ==== {{anchor|Flight 24}} On May 6, 2016, Falcon 9 flight 24 delivered the [[JCSAT-14]] satellite on a [[geostationary transfer orbit]] (GTO) while the first stage conducted a re-entry burn under ballistic conditions without prior boostback. Following the controlled descent through the atmosphere, the booster executed a short landing burn as it approached the drone ship ''Of Course I Still Love You'', and succeeded in landing vertically. This second landing at sea was more difficult than the previous one because the booster at separation was traveling about {{convert|8350|km/h|abbr=on}} compared to {{convert|6650|km/h|abbr=on}} on the CRS-8 launch to [[low Earth orbit]].<ref name="SpaceX">{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7pUAydjne5M|title=CRS-8 Dragon Hosted Webcast|first=|last=SpaceX|date=April 8, 2016|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref name="SpaceX"/> Pursuing their experiments to test the limits of the [[flight envelope]], SpaceX opted for a shorter landing burn with three engines instead of the single-engine burns seen in earlier attempts; this approach consumes less fuel by leaving the stage in free fall as long as possible and decelerating more sharply, thereby minimizing the amount of energy expended to counter gravity.<ref name="musk-tweet-20160506"> {{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |author-link=Elon Musk |number=728462267893698561 |date=May 6, 2016 |access-date=May 8, 2016 |title=Yeah, this was a three engine landing burn, so triple deceleration of last flight. That's important to minimize gravity losses. }}</ref> Elon Musk indicated this first stage may not be flown again and will instead be used as a life leader for ground tests to confirm future first stage rockets are good.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.floridatoday.com/story/tech/science/space/spacex/2016/05/16/landed-spacex-rocket-suffered-max-damage/84454230/|title=SpaceX Falcon 9 first stage booster suffered 'max' damage on landing|publisher=}}</ref>
==== Flight 25 ==== On May 27, 2016, Falcon 9 flight 25 delivered [[Thaicom 8|THAICOM 8]] to a supersynchronous transfer orbit; despite high re-entry speed, the first stage again landed successfully on the SpaceX drone ship.<ref name="mashable20160402">{{cite web |last=Kramer |first=Miriam |title=SpaceX does it again: Company lands third rocket on drone ship in the ocean |url=http://mashable.com/2016/05/27/spacex-drone-ship-third-landing/ |date=27 May 2016 |work=[[Mashable]] |accessdate=28 May 2016}}</ref> The landing crushed a "crush core" in one leg, leading to a notable tilt to the stage as it stood on the drone ship.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wall|first1=Mike|title=SpaceX's Leaning Rocket Tower Comes Ashore (Photos)|url=http://www.space.com/33102-spacex-leaning-rocket-comes-ashore-photos.html|accessdate=7 June 2016|date=7 June 2016}}</ref>
==== Flight 26 ==== On June 15, 2016, [[Falcon 9 flight 26]] successfully delivered the [[Eutelsat]] 117W B<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/SpaceX/status/743095831088091141|title=SpaceX on Twitter|website=Twitter|access-date=2016-06-15}}</ref> and [[ABS (satellite operator)|ABS]] 2A<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/SpaceX/status/743097021347700736|title=SpaceX on Twitter|website=Twitter|access-date=2016-06-15}}</ref> satellites into GTO. The first stage conducted a re-entry burn and successfully deployed its grid fins, before attempting a landing on the barge. The landing failed in its final moments due to low thrust on one of the first stage engines, caused by the exhaustion of its liquid oxygen fuel supply. That caused the engines to shut down early while the first stage was just above the drone's deck, causing a landing failure.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/743096769001578498|title=Elon Musk on Twitter|website=Twitter|access-date=2016-06-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/elonmusk/status/743097337782763521|title=Elon Musk on Twitter|website=Twitter|access-date=2016-06-15}}</ref>
==== Flight 27 ==== In the early hours of July 18, 2016, Falcon 9 flight 27, carrying the [[Dragon spacecraft]] for the [[CRS-9]] mission was followed by a successful landing of the first stage at [[Landing Zone 1]], [[CCAFS|Cape Canaveral]].<ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/spacex-launch-iss-docking-port-nasa-1.3683338 SpaceX launches space station docking port for NASA], The Associated Press, July 18, 2016</ref>
==== Flight 28 ==== On August 14, 2016, the Falcon 9 flight 28 successfully propelled the Japanese [[JCSAT-16]] telecommunications satellite to a [[geosynchronous transfer orbit]]. The first stage [[atmospheric re-entry|re-entered the atmosphere]] and landed vertically on the ''Of Course I Still Love You'' drone ship that was located in the Atlantic Ocean.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://spaceflightnow.com/2016/08/14/falcon-9-rocket-launches-japanese-satellite-then-nails-bullseye-landing/ |title= Falcon 9 rocket launches Japanese satellite, then nails bullseye landing |work=Spaceflight Now |first=Stephen |last=Clark |date=14 August 2016}}</ref>
== Transition to routine reuse == {{Further|List of Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy launches#Future launches}} SpaceX continued to return a number of first stages in both ground and sea landings to clarify the procedures needed to re-use flown boosters. The company had hoped to begin offering pre-flown Falcon 9 rocket stages commercially by the end of 2016,<ref> {{cite web |url=http://spaceflight101.com/returned-falcon-9-booster-fires-up-for-static-fire-test/ |work=Spaceflight 101 |title=Returned Falcon 9 Booster fires up for Static Fire Test |date=January 15, 2016 |accessdate=January 18, 2016 }}</ref><ref name="musk-refly"> {{cite news |title=Musk: SpaceX Plans to Re-Fly Falcon 9 in June |url=http://innerspace.net/launch-vehicle-development/musk-spacex-plans-to-re-fly-falcon-9-in-june/ |first=Stewart |last=Money |work=Innerspace.net |date=April 9, 2016 |access-date=May 8, 2016 |quote=Having previously suggested that SpaceX would like to re-fly a Falcon 9 first stage by the end of the year, Musk surprised nearly everyone by confidently asserting that the time frame was instead late May or more realistically June. Moreover, the odds were favorable that it would be a paying launch. }}</ref> but the first re-used booster eventually took off on March 30, 2017 with the [[SES-10]] mission. The booster performed well and was recovered a second time.
In January 2016 Musk evaluated the likelihood of success to approximately 70 percent for landing attempts in 2016, hopefully rising to 90 percent in 2017; he also cautioned that the company expected "a few more RUDs", referring to the term ''Rapid Unscheduled Disassembly'', a humorous euphemism for destruction of the vehicle.<ref name="musk-tweet-20160119">{{cite tweet |user=elonmusk |author-link=Elon Musk |number=689299216607232000 |date=January 19, 2016 |access-date=May 8, 2016 |title=My best guess for 2016: ~70% landing success rate (so still a few more RUDs to go), then hopefully improving to ~90% in 2017 }}</ref> Musk's prediction were close to the actual numbers, as five out of eight flown boosters ({{percent|5|8}}) were recovered in 2016, and 14 out of 14 ({{percent|14|14}}) in 2017. Three GTO missions for heavy payloads were flown in an [[expendable launch system|expendable]] configuration, not equipped for landing. Five boosters were flown a second time in 2017, marking the beginning of routine reuse of boosters.
<gallery class=center widths=160 heights=170> File:Falcon 9 first stage attempts landing on ASDS after CRS-6 (17170624412).jpg|Falcon 9 first-stage attempts landing on the [[Autonomous spaceport drone ship]], the landing legs are in the midst of deploying File:CRS-6 first stage booster landing attempt.jpg|Falcon 9 Flight 17's first-stage attempting a controlled landing on the drone ship following the successful launch of CRS-6 File:ORBCOMM-2 First-Stage Landing (23271687254).jpg|Falcon 9 flight 20's first-stage moments before touchdown on Landing Zone 1 File:Falcon 9 Flight 20 OG2 first stage post-landing (23273082823) cropped.jpg|Falcon 9 flight 20's first-stage after landing File:First stage of Jason-3 rocket (24382360351).jpg| Falcon 9 flight 21's landing approach before it soft-landed and tipped over due to a leg lock failure File:CRS-8 first stage landing (26366878046).jpg |Falcon 9 flight 23's first-stage was the first successful landing on the drone ship File:JCSAT-14 first stage on droneship (26820653346).jpg|Falcon 9 flight 24's first stage on the drone ship File:THAICOM 8 first-stage landing (27387436926).jpg|Falcon 9 flight 25 first-stage approached the drone ship with a tilt </gallery>
